estimate.translation[0].definitions[0].d: a calculation of the value, size, amount etc of something made using the information that you have, which may not be complete
estimate.translation[0].definitions[0].e: We just need an estimate of the number of people who will come.
estimate.translation[0].definitions[1].d: a statement of how much it will probably cost to build or repair something
estimate.translation[0].definitions[1].e: The garage said they’d send me an estimate for the work.
estimate.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: make an estimate
Insurers have to make an estimate of the risk involved.
give an estimate
The builder gave me an estimate of £10,000.
provide (somebody with) an estimate
Could you ask him if he can provide us with an estimate?
put an estimate on something
It is impossible to put an estimate on the value of the manuscript.
an estimate puts something at something
Independent estimates put the number of refugees at 50,000.
base an estimate on something
The government based its estimate on data from the 2008 census.
a rough/approximate estimate
Can you give me a rough estimate of how much the repairs will cost?
an accurate/reliable estimate
It’s hard to put an accurate estimate on the number of people affected.
a conservative estimate
By conservative estimates, 2.5 million people die each year from smoking cigarettes.
an official estimate
According to official army estimates, more than 500 rebels had been killed.
current/recent estimates
According to current estimates, the country can expect 200,000 visitors in the next three years.
the latest estimates
The latest estimates are that sea levels could rise by about 20 cm by 2050.
earlier/previous estimates
These amounts are much higher than those given in previous estimates.
the original estimate
The final cost was nearly three times the original estimate.
according to an estimate
According to some estimates, an acre of forest is cleared every minute.
estimates range/vary from ... to ...
Estimates of the number of homeless people in the city range from 6,000 to 10,000.
estimate.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to try to judge the value, size, speed, cost etc of something, without calculating it exactly
estimate.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The tree is estimated to be at least 700 years old.
Scientists estimate that smoking reduces life expectancy by around 12 years on average.
It is not easy to estimate how many people have the disease.
estimate.translation[1].definitions[0].n: In more formal English, you say it is estimated that something is true
It is estimated that the statue weighs 60 tons
estimate.translation[2].definitions[0].d: a calculation of what the value, size, amount etc of something will probably be
estimate.translation[2].definitions[0].e: They were able to give us a rough estimate (=a not very exact one) of the cost.
Even the most conservative estimates (=deliberately low) suggest we need to build one million new homes.
estimate.translation[2].definitions[1].d: a statement of how much it will probably cost to build or repair something
estimate.translation[2].definitions[1].e: Get several estimates before starting any building work.
Nuclear power stations are notoriously unreliable and construction costs go way over original estimates.
estimate.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to calculate what you think the value, size, amount etc of something is or will probably be
estimate.translation[3].definitions[0].e: Officials estimate that supply has exceeded demand by £7.5 billion since the beginning of 2005.
The value of the deal is estimated at £12 million.
